statements: Tech companies should treat user data as a stewardship responsibility: design products to minimize collection and retention, secure information with strong technical safeguards, and disclose uses in clear, plain language so individuals can make informed choices. Meaningful consent, accessible controls, independent audits, and enforceable remedies create a predictable framework that preserves innovation while protecting dignity and public safety.

Companies must balance the public benefits of data-driven services with a fiduciary duty to protect individuals by embedding privacy-by-design, limiting data to defined purposes, and using techniques like encryption and de-identification for legitimate research. Transparent policies, data portability, and independent oversight ensure accountability and give users real control without needlessly blocking beneficial innovation.

Handle personal information as a shared trust: collect only what is necessary, protect it with auditable security measures, and offer straightforward, machine- and human-readable choices so families and vulnerable communities are safeguarded. Coordinated industry standards and sensible regulation, combined with timely breach notification and clear redress, build the trust required for technology to serve the common good.

A practical middle path asks companies to minimize data collection, secure what they hold, and empower users with easy controls and clear choices, while regulators and industry set predictable standards and oversight.
